revised_title: Smallpox Transmission through Pustules: A Historical Account
tldr: The author, Richard Wright, describes a common practice in 18th-century England where people would buy the contents of smallpox pustules from infected individuals to intentionally contract the disease. This practice was widespread and considered a way to build immunity against the potentially fatal illness. The author provides several accounts of people who had successfully acquired the smallpox through this method, but also mentions a tragic case where a young woman died after receiving the matter from a person with a severe case of smallpox.
scientific_discipline: Medicine and Health Sciences > Infectious Diseases
